Learn Terminal Project

An iOS Project

About the project

The Learn Terminal Project is about teaching basic Unix commands to use in the command line. The user can hit the plus button from the UINavigationBar to select from a number of ordinary language commands (i.e. “list files”) and add ordinary language options (i.e. “ignore case”), and then the appropriate command with flags shows up in a little terminal window below (i.e. find ~ -iname pictureofcat.jpg”).

Behind the scenes

The commands are created via a struct that uses a friendly name property for the ordinary language description, a root command property for the root unix command, and an array of options property to construct the rest of the String. The options are created via three classes: SelectCommand (grouped tables), CheckCommand (switches), and TextCommand (text fields). Typecasting is used both to create the final string and to create custom table view cells.

Style

Stylistically, I sought to make the terminal area look as much like a terminal as possible. I did this by using a black background with white text, the menlo-bold UIFont (one of only two monospaced fonts available in iOS), and an alert controller with text fields that prompts the user to enter a username and computer name so that I create the typical ComputerName:DirectoryName Username$ CL prompt.

Custom UIAlertControllers

But I actually went through a number of iterations on my alerts. My original alert controller had some dull greyed out text explaining the AC. So I started going down the rabbit hole of making custom ACs by writing an extension to UIAlertController.

Human Interface Guidelines

Although not only did that look hideous, it probably wouldn’t get through Apple’s review process, as you are supposed to use the ACs as is. According to Apple’s Human Interface Guidelines (AHIG) we should avoid explaining the alert buttons, because if the button titles are clear, then it shouldn’t require additional explanation.

And I used .destructive as the style because as per AHIG, should appear in red and I provided a cancel button marked .cancel so that it appears in bold at the bottom to instill confidence that you can abandon the destructive task. And I think the final result is far more clear and less clown like.
